top_categories.workout_context: Turnhout Gravel's Belgian rolling, European gravel forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 70 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Turnhout Gravel's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before August.
50ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At Turnhout Gravel, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
When someone attacks on belgian rolling gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Turnhout Gravel. Train it until it feels boring.
70 miles on belgian rolling gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Turnhout Gravel, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
Varied gradients on belgian rolling gravel demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on belgian rolling gravel. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 3,500ft of climbing on belgian rolling gravel does to your power file on race day.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Turnhout Gravel’s 70 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Turnhout Gravel requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on belgian rolling gravel to build confidence. Expect: belgian rolling, european gravel, regional event.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 70 miles of belgian rolling gravel in Turnhout, Belgium.
